title: sajid javid urges public wear
story: Sajid Javid urges public to wear face masks - hours after Tories refuse to in CommonsThe Health Secretary urged people to consider wearing a mask in busy places but did not make them compulsory again. His comments came just hours after ministers gathered in the Commons for PMQsSajid Javid said people should wear face masks in enclosed spaces Image: Getty ImagesByChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsSajid Javid has said the public should wear a face mask to think about others around them in some enclosed settings just hours after Tory MPs packed into the House of Commons without them. The Health Secretary, who did not wear a face mask in the Commons today, urged people to consider wearing a mask in busy places such as public transport but did not make them compulsory again. At tonightaposs press conference, he said: There are many things we can all do, like wearing face coverings in crowded or close spaces.His comments came just hours after ministers gathered in the Commons for Prime Ministeraposs Questionsand most Tory MPs did not wear a face mask when sitting next to others. Mr Javid came under fire over his colleaguesapos behaviour - and one Tory MPaposs plans to hold a Christmas party - during todayaposs Downing Street press conference.  He responded to a question about their actions contradicting official advice by saying aposI think thataposs a very fair pointapos. Weaposve all got a role to play and set an example to set as private iniduals as well. Itaposs a very fair point and Iaposm sure a lot of people have heard you, he added. Mr Javid added that the Government is not currently planning to implement its Plan B for tackling coronavirus, adding that ministers do not believe the pressures on the NHS are unsustainable at the moment. Responding to questions, he said: “You said, am I sayingwe don’t do our bit, get vaccinated, all those behavioural changes we can make, that we are more likely to face restrictions as we head into winter - then I am saying that. “I think we’ve been really clear that we’ve all got a role to play. “If not enough people get their booster jabs,not enough of those people who were eligible for the original offer - the million that remain unvaccinated -they don’t come forward. “If people don’t wear masks when they really should in a really crowded place with lots of people they don’t normally hang out with. “If they’re not washing their hands and stuff - it’s going to hit us all. and it would of course make it more likely we’re going to have more restrictions.“Now we want to avoid those, we’ve set out what those restrictions might look like, we’ve set out the Plan B restrictions for example, and we all want to avoid those.”In his first-ever Downing Street press conference, Sajid Javid repeated his warning that Covid- cases could reach , a day as the country enters a challenging winter period.He said the UK was seeing greater pressure on the NHS but said the Government will do what it takes to make sure that this pressure doesnapost become unsustainable and that we donapost allow the NHS to become overwhelmed. He said deaths remain mercully low at the moment, even though in the past week almost a thousand people died after contracting the disease. He added: Weaposve always known that the winter months would pose the greatest threat to our road to recovery.  He added: Thanks to the vaccination programme, the link between hospitalisations and deaths has signicantly weakened, but itaposs not broken. So we must all remember that this virus will be with us for the long term and remains a threat to our loved ones, and a threat to the progress that weaposve made in getting our nation closer to normal le. The latest Government figures show that a further  people have died within  days of testing positive for Covid- as of Wednesday. As of am on Wednesday, there have been a further , lab-confirmed Covid- cases in the UK. Hospital admissions stand at  on average per day over the last seven days, up from  a week earlier, a rise of  per cent.  Earlier, Matthew Taylor, chief executive of the NHS Confederation which represents health bodies, warned that we risk stumbling into a winter crisis unless measures such as face masks and vaccine passports - the Governmentaposs Plan B for the coming months - are introduced in England. He called for ministers to come up with a Plan C of even tougher restrictionsthose measures are insufficient to address pressure on the health service. A behavioural expert has predicted thatthe Government made face masks compulsory again, most people in England would follow the rule.  Professor Linda Bauld said the nation is the outlier in the UK when it comes to coronavirus safety measures, as many aspects included in the Westminster Governmentaposs Plan B are already in place in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The behavioural scientist, who is Professor of Public Health at the University of Edinburgh, said the main issue is communication and added that making something mandatory is a big sht which sends a message that people need to comply. Under the Governmentaposs current Plan A strategy, people in England are advised to wear a face covering in crowded and enclosed settings but it is not a legal requirement. Prof Bauld said it is striking and very unfortunate that most Conservative MPs sit in the House of Commons without masks, compared with those on the opposition benches who have generally been seen to wear face coverings. She said: Leaders need to lead by example and with thesenumbers and the concerns we have, absolutely, I think politicians from all parties should be wearing a face covering when theyaposre in the chamber, when they canapost distance etc. Itaposs social norms that drive these behaviours. When you mandate something, itaposs a big sht, it sends a message that itaposs expected and therefore you need to comply unless thereaposs an exception. She added: I think there are some people who feel quite comfortable still wearing one and donapost care what anybody  thinks, but there are others who do , and so, therefore, I think just saying we recommend it but itaposs not required isnapost strong enough. It just doesnapost really work. title: single use items not just
story: All single use items - not just plastic - could face charges in ‘throwaway culture’ clampdownMinisters look to ramp up green powers ahead of the UN COP climate change conference in GlasgowAll single-use items could face new charges Image: Lancs LiveByRachel Wearmouth:,  Oct | commentsExtra charges on all single-use items - not just plastic - will be part of a Government crackdown on throwaway culture. The move could mean the p charge on plastic carriers could be replicated for many other things, such as coffee stirrers and straws. Ministers are set to announce the new green powers in the Commons on Wednesday.It comes as Boris Johnson prepares to host the UN COP climate change summit in Glasgow later this month.It is hoped the charges will nudge consumers to use more sustainable items, after the plastic carrier bag charge cut sales in main supermarkets by %. The bill already contained laws to make it easier for ministers to introduce charges on single-use plastics, but the amendments push to introduce charges on all single-use products. “This change to the Environment Bill will mean we can put an end to ‘here-today gone-tomorrow’ throwaway culture and move towards sustainable alternatives,” a Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs source has said. The campaign has been led by Labour ’s Shadow Environment Minister Baroness Jones of Whitchurch, who has been pushing for the change in the Government’s flagship Environment Bill.“This concession is an important first step in reducing our reliance on single-use items, which have an environmental cost whether they are made out of plastic or other materials such as wood, she told The i paper. “While we have welcomed the Government’s incremental bans on certain plastic items, it is clear that ministers need a wider range of tools to tackle the throw-away culture that creates unnecessary waste and litter.” Ruth Chambers of the Greener UK coalition said: “This is very welcome news. “A plastics only measure would have simply moved producers and consumers to single use alternatives that are often unrecyclable. “It is right that the Environment Bill should tackle our throwaway culture head on.” The levy on plastic carrier bags increased to p from p on May  and now applies to every retailer, from giant supermarket chains to corner shops, small clothes boutiques, butchers, greengrocers and airport duty-free stores Before this, the p levy only applied only to shops with more than  staff but it has resulted in the average person in England buying just four bags a year from the big store chains – a massive reduction from  bags each in . While it is thought the new scheme for all single-use items could be similar, the full details are not yet known. title: the online world become toxic
story: The online world has become toxic for too many of us - we need changeAfter a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do, writes Labours Jo Stevens MP, Shadow Digital SecretaryThe online world has become toxicImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByJo Stevens, Shadow Digital Secretary:,  Oct | commentsWe all know that the online world has become toxic for too many of us. From abusive behaviour that causes real damage and shuts down debate to the extremism that spreads terrying ideas and incites people to commit murder. After a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do.As the testimony from Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen has shown, making money is all these companies care about.Facebook knew its app was damaging children’s mental health but chose to do nothing. Imaginea drugs company was selling something that made kids sick or a toy firm was selling dangerous a product, they would rightly suffer severe consequences.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  The first change we need in the Bill is to include criminal sanctions against the senior executives of the big companies for repeated breaches of the new law. We need a strong incentive to change the culture of those companies and how they operate. Without personal liability, nothing will change. And we know this works, we have it in health and safety law and in banking. Itaposs not good enough that the Conservatives left this out of their draft Bill.And it should not have taken Keir Starmer to push on this at PMQs for Boris Johnson to perform a U-turn.Another big omission from the Bill is a tough rule around legal but harmful content like racist abuse suffered by our footballers, misogyny suffered by just about any woman in public le and other abuse that makes le a misery but doesn’t hit a criminal threshold.  We need a tough duty of care on the companies which covers all that abuse because it can’t be left up to social media companies to self police it. They have already shown they can’t, or won’t do it voluntarily.After England lost the Euros final, Instagram said that monkey emojis used to attack Saka and other black players did not breach its rules. So self regulation by these companies has had its day. Finally there is a big worry that this Bill has a two tier approach to digital s putting tougher rules in place for the big “category ” sites like Facebook and Twitter but putting less stringent rules in place for the smaller sites.But as Hope Not Hate and the Anti Semitism Policy Trust and others have warned, it’s often the smaller s that host the most terrying and dangerous content with Twitter and Facebook acting as a shop window for the more extreme material. Labour believes this needs to be addressed because excluding these sites from stronger rules is playing into the hands of those who want to spread this dangerous extremism.On Wednesday, under pressure from Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister promised to bring in criminal sanctions and to bring forward the second reading of the Bill before Christmas. We will be holding him to these promises. We need our laws in place as soon as possible and for them to be effective to make all our online lives safer. Because we know from bitter experience that harms against people online can quickly move offline. story: Some Tory MPs refuse to wear masks despite Sajid Javids plea to set an exampleHealth Secretary Sajid Javid said MP have a role to play in this as he urged people to wear masks in enclosed spacesSome MPs were not wearing masks in the Commons on Thursday Image: Parliament TVByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsTory MPs have been accused of utter hypocrisy as some failed to wear face masks in the Commons - despite being urged to set an example by the Health Secretary. Sajid Javid appealed to the public to wear masks in enclosed spaces to curb rising infection rates and admitted that MPs should lead the way in Parliament.At a Downing Street press conference on Wednesday, Mr Javid was pressed on whether MPs should have donned face coverings at Prime Ministeraposs Questions in the packed Commons chamber. He replied: “I think that is a very fair point. As I say, we’ve all got our role to play in this. But some MPs were still flouting the advice on Thursday morning.  When the Mirror did a headcount at .am, we saw  MPs on the government benches - seven with masks and seven without. By comparison there were  MPs on the opposition benches,  with masks and one without.Tory MPs wearing masks included Jeremy Hunt while those without masks included lockdown sceptic MPs Desmond Swayne and Mark Harper.Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran said: “It is utter hypocrisy that the public are rightfully being advised to wear masks while Conservative MPs refuse to do so. “The very same day that Sajid Javid was urging the public to take steps to protect themselves against the virus, Conservative MPs were laid across the green benches maskless and irresponsible.In the Commons, Vaccines Minister Maggie Throup said she was wearing her mask “out of choice because it’s the right thing to do”, when pressed on the issue by the SNP ’s Peter Grant.Tory former minister Dr Andrew Murrison challenged the minister on the obsession with non-pharmaceutical interventions, such as mask wearing, which he claimed would obscure the focus on the vaccination programme.  Lockdown-sceptic backbencher Sir Desmond Swayne also said the mask would deny us the fellowship and reassurance of her friendly facial expression. Ms Throup replied: I look forward to the time we donapost need to wear face coverings because I love to see everyoneaposs smiling faces, but we do need to make sure that we all get jabbed so we can get to that stage. On masks, she said: Plan A outlines the guidance that we have in place and thataposs the guidance that people should be following, and itaposs up to iniduals to work out what works for them and whataposs best for them. Plan B incorporates mandatory wearing of masks but weaposre on plan A. Earlier, Shadow Culture Secretary Jo Stevens said the vast majority of opposition MPs have been wearing masks throughout.She told TimesRadio it appeared that Tory MPs were being whippednot to wear masks in the Chamber.I donapost understand why Conservative Party MPs... it almost felt like they were being whipped not to wear masks in the chamber. I donapost know whether they were or not but itaposs been a very odd situation. Finally, last night Sajid Javid was saying he would recommend that people wear masks and yet his government colleagues and fellow Tory MPs donapost wear them. Downing Street stopped short of backing Mr Javidaposs call for MPs to wear masks in the crowded Commons chamber. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: It remains the case that itaposs a matter of personal judgment for all iniduals on wearing a mask. We have very clear guidance which sets out that people are recommended to wear face coverings in crowded, enclosed spaces where they come into contact with people they do not normally meet. Jacob Rees-Mogg also refused to back the calls - and claimed Tories didnapost need to wear them as they know each other and have a convivial fraternal spirit. The Tory Commons Leader said: There is no advice to wear face masks in workplaces. The advice on crowded spaces is with crowded spaces with people that you donapost know. We on this side know each other. He joked that it may be that the honourable gentleman doesnapost like mixing with his own side, adding but we on this side have a more convivial, fraternal spirit, and therefore are following the guidance of Her Majestyaposs Government. It comes as the Government resisted calls to implement plan B of its Covid winter plan, which includes wearing masks, vaccine passports and ing to working from home. title: what covid plan c what
story: What is Covid Plan C - and what could trigger new lockdown measures Health Secretary Sajid Javid rejected calls to impose Covid contingency plans - as medics accused the Government of being wilfully negligent in the face of rising cases. Here we look at what measures could come in, from mandatory masks to banning household mixing Image: Adam Gerrard   Daily MirrorByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Government is resisting calls to trigger Covid contingency plans despite warnings that the number of cases could rise to , a day. Doctors accused ministers of being wilfully negligent by failing to implement Covid Plan B, which would see theof masks, working from home and use of vaccine passports.Health Secretary Sajid Javid claimed that the NHS was facing a sustainable level of pressure as the winter approaches and said further curbs would not be brought in at the moment.But he raised the threat of new restrictions before Christmaspeople didnapost get their booster jabs. It comes as Cabinet Office officials were said to be discussing plans to curb household mixing - which could form part of a “Plan C” -booster jabs donapost bring the virus under control.  Health Minister Ed Argar said plan C was not being actively considered and insisted current measures are working. Boris Johnson insisted that Government was sticking with its winter Covid plan despite the high number of infections. Speaking during a visit to a school in County Antrim, the Prime Minister said: The numbers of infections are high but weaposre within the parameters of what the predictions were. We are continuing with the plan we set out in July. We are watching the numbers very carefully every day, he said. The numbers of infections are high but we are within the parameters of what the predictions were, what Spi-Mand the others said we would be at this stage given the steps we are taking. We are sticking with our plan. But thereaposs an almighty row brewing over whether the Government is on course to repeat last yearaposs mistakes by taking lockdown measures too late in the face of spiralling infections. Hereaposs what we know about the plans to battle the virus this winter. What is the Covid winter plan  The Government published a blueprint on how it intends to battle Covid over the colder months in September. The UK is currently following Plan A, which relies on booster jabs for the over-s and other vulnerable groups, as well as jabs to  to -year-olds to keep the virus at bay. It also advises people to wear masks in enclosed spaces, although it is not mandatory. But there are mounting fears that the booster programme is moving too slowly, with reports of chaotic rollouts for in care homes. And infections have been on the rise, with , cases as of am on Wednesday. Hospital admissions stand at  on average per day over the last seven days, up from  a week earlier, a rise of %. Scientic experts have warned that the UK is probably already close to , cases a day. The worrying figures have prompted calls for the Government to do more to curb the spread of the virus.  What is aposPlan Bapos  The -page Winter plan contains a list of tougher measures known as Plan B, which will be deployedthe NHS in England comes under unsustainable pressure. Masks would become mandatory in certain settings, and vaccine passports would be made a legal requirement for nightclubs, outdoor festivals and football matches. Brits could be ordered to work from home againthey can, and there will be public information campaigns to communicate the change of risk to the public. What needs to happen to move to aposPlan Bapos  The Government has refused to say explicitly - but we can take some educated guesses. The aim of the Covid winter plan is to ensure the NHS does not come under unsustainable pressure. This means keeping a close eye on the number of people being hospitalised with the virus, as well as whether the link between infections and hospitalisations remains weak. Vaccine efficacy is also key as the success of the UKaposs vaccine rollout has been crucial to easing Covid restrictions. The presence of any deadly new iants is also a key factor, so ministers are keeping a close eye on a new strain called AY.., which some are calling Delta Plus.Plan B might not all be imposed at onceministers do hit go on the plan. Boris Johnson previously described it as a number of dferent shots in the lockercases started rising. What is aposPlan Capos - and will household mixing be banned  Cabinet Office officials are said to be discussing a ban on household mixing before Christmasboosters fail to bring the virus under control. Health Minister Edward Argar said the plan wasnapost being actively considered but the Government would always look at ways to prevent the virus spiralling out of control. But a Whitehall source told the : The focus is very much on measures that can be taken without a major economic impact, so keeping shops, pubs and restaurants open but looking at other ways to reduce the risks.” Downing Street insisted neither ministers or officials are working on those proposals and there were no plans to move to Plan B at the moment. The national ban on indoor meet-ups was lted on May  after being in place for the last lockdown. It remained in place after shops and pubs reopened as experts suggested people were more likely to ignore social distancing guidancethey are at home with their friends and loved ones. What about foreign travel  Rules around international travel have just been relaxed, with the old traffic light rules scrapped and replaced with a single red list. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has also announced that day  PCR tests can be replaced with cheaper lateral flows from next week, to make holidays cheaper for families. None of this gives a sense that the Government is planning to scrap foreign travel again and there is no mention of ending overseas travel in the winter plan. Will there be another lockdown  Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng was the latest top Tory to rule out ato a national lockdown. Boris Johnson is desperate to avoid a lockdown - and it would only ever be imposed as a last resort due to the widespread disruption to peopleaposs lives. Working from home is one of the big levers the Government can pull to reduce the spread of the virus, as well as banning household mixing. It is likely that these measures would be imposed before the Government even considered a full lockdown. And remember - we didnapost have the vaccine last winter, which is the best protection we have against the virus. title: 10 things you need know
story: things you need to know about COP ahead of Glasgow conferenceThe COP summit is set to take place in Glasgow between October  and November , with major figures including the Queen, Sir David Attenborough and Barack Obama set to attendSir David Attenborough is set to attend the COP conference in Glasgow Image: Getty ImagesByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWorld leaders will descend on Glasgow this month for the th United Nations Climate Change Conference. The COP summit is taking place between October  and November , with more than , delegates set to attend.Politicians are expected to thrash out deals which will help countries tackle climate change and limit global temperature changes to .C. The Queen, Sir David Attenborough, Barack Obama and Joe Biden are just a few of the major figures expected to appear at the summit. Here are the  things you need to know about COP: What is COP  COP stands for ‘conference of the parties’, the annual meeting of the countries that are members of the UN Climate Convention. These meetings have taken place since the convention was set up in Rio, Brazil, in . Since then, negotiators from most countries decide what actions need to be taken under international law to protect the climate.  COP takes place from October  – November  in Glasgow, Scotland, and is the UK’s first time playing host, in partnership with Italy. It was originally planned for November , but the pandemic forced a reschedule. The conference is opening a day earlier than planned, because of Covid-. The talks are scheduled to end at pm on Friday  November, but past experience of Cops shows they are likely to extend into the Saturday or even Sunday. Who will attend  More than , delegates from  countries will descend on Glasgow from October st, alongside some  heads of state. The world leaders, around  expected, will gather in the first few days and then depart leaving the complex negotiations to their representatives. The UK is expecting a full house from the EU - including a last hurrah for Merkel - while Biden is bringing  cabinet members and Barack Obama.  Canada, Australia, Korea, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Argentina are among others confirmed. Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are some of the world leaders who are understood not to have confirmed their attendance in Glasgow, despite the Prime Minister calling on the country to put forward ambitious targets in a call last week. Ramaphosa and Japanaposs new PM Kishida have local elections so may miss out. North Korea Ambassador Choe Il will make the trip. Up to , climate activists, influencers and experts are also expected to show up. That includes broadcaster and natural historian Sir David Attenborough, who will address world leaders as a people’s advocate.The Queen will attend COP along with former U.S. President Barack Obama who will join current president Joe Biden. In a U-turn, so will youth climate activist Greta Thunberg. Thunberg previously refused to attend due to concerns that delegates from poorer countries would not be able to go to the event due to a lack of access to COVID- vaccines.Thousands of demonstrators are also expected.  Why is Cop important  This is the first COP since the Paris Agreement, which set out to radically decrease emissions, which will see membersto the table to state exactly what they are going to do. Adopted in , it is a landmark agreement to combat climate change unites all the worldaposs nations in a single agreement for the first time in history. The Key points were to keep global temperatures well below .Cabove pre-industrial times and endeavour to limit them even more, to .C. Also to limit the amount of greenhouse gases emitted by human activity to the same levels that trees, soil and oceans can absorb naturally, beginning at some point between  and . So far  countries and the EU have revised their actions - also known as National Determined Contributions . These have to be revisited every five years and COP marks the deadline, which has already been extended as a result of the pandemic. What is hoped to be achieved in Glasgow  It is broadly accepted there are three headline targets for COP: To keep .C in reach by ensuring all major polluters deliver new plans. To deliver a green recovery and finance package for developing countries, including the bn but also plans to fund adaptation and loss  damage. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterSign off a range of deals on carbon markets, transparency, agreed timetables for national climate plans, coal, forests, development bank climate finance goals  ICE end dates that will accelerate and smooth the global transition through the s Why is .C signicant  Half a degree might not sound like much but it is the dference between le and death for low-lying coastal countries like Bangladesh and Males being wiped out due to rising sea levels. The projected harm to wildle and ecosystems increases enormously between global heating of .C and anything higher. At C, experts say there will be almost no coral reefs left, the Arctic will be ice-free in summer once a decade and huge numbers of animals and plants will be extinct. The chance of flooding will increase by %. How warm is it now  Temperatures around the world are already at about . – .C above pre-industrial levels, and greenhouse gas emissions are still on an upward trend.  Will this impact the UK Yes. A report by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change earlier this year said weather events once rare or unprecedented are becoming more common.It said that it will continue evenglobal heating is limited to .C. It also said that climate change is unequivocally being driven by human activity, which fuels these extreme weather patterns. What happensCop fails “COP was always going to be extremely tough, UK PM Boris Johnson told Bloomberg this week.The big players in the talks – the UN, the UK, the US – have already conceded that Cop will not achieve everything that was hoped for as the NDCs likely to emerge will not add up to all that is needed to ensure the world remains within .C.  That is disappointing for many observers, but is not a surprise given the complexity of the negotiations. China, India, Saudi Arabia and Turkey are the G nations yet to submit anything pre COP - although to give Ankara credit, they have finally signed up to the Paris Agreement six years after it was agreed What the UK hosts are now focused on is ensuring that there is enough progress on emissions cuts for  to “keep .C alive”, and to pursue as many other routes – phasing out coal, cutting methane and setting a path away from fossil fuels for transport etc. November Rain Tensions are rising as Cop approaches with rail workers and waste collectors going on strike, Airbnb are screwing over customers who have already booked accommodation in the city by asking for more money and Covid rates are rising.  Speaking for a planet, even the Queen piled in: “It is very irritating when they talk, but they donapost do,” she said, in a nod to national climate plansyet to land. Can I go to COP  Yes and no. In order to attend, only accredited delegates, media and politicians will have access to what is known as the Blue Zone - the area of venue managed by the UN.COPs also have a green zone, managed by the Presidency, with events for the wider public. story: Blind woman screamed at after politely asking man to stop petting her guide dogDr Amy Kavangh said the pair are often put into dangerous situations by passers-by wanting to fuss over the dogDr Kavangh was screamed at after asking someone to stop petting Ava Image: BlondeHistorian TwitterByKieren Williams:,  Oct | commentsA blind woman says she was screamed at after she politely asked someone to stop petting her guide dog. Dr Amy Kavanagh, who has been visually impaired since birth, was paired with her Ava a year ago but despite her dog’s training she says they are regularly put in danger by passers-by wanting to fuss over the animal. She shared her experiences and has even recorded a video from Avaaposs point of view after Guide Dogs revealed figures that show % of guide dog owners claim their dog is distracted by strangers at least once a day and % said it happens at least once a week. This comes as new figures from the Guide Dogs charity revealed that % of owners claim their dog is distracted by strangers at least once a day, and % said it happens at least once a week.  The charity also polled the public and found three in  Brits freely admitted to stopping and interrupting a guide dog while it was working by petting it. Dr Kavangh said: People will try and pet her or whistle at her while she is working and it can be confusing for me because she is my eyes. If she stops and does a dferent movement, I can think itaposs because of a hazard like a set of steps or a car on the pavement and it can be really stressful or frightening.” Dr Kavangh said that Ava sometimes has “a little cry” after getting distracted because the guide dog becomes distressed.  Dr Kavanagh said someone tries to love Ava pretty much every time the pair are out. She added: I had a woman pet her earlier this week just as Ava was showing me where the gap was at a train . That is the real risk and not to sound dramatic but we could die. She could be stopping me walking out in front of cars or falling down the stairs. She explained how it was “a bit entitled” that people put their desire to play with a dog over her boundaries and safety. Dr Kavanagh understood sometimes it came from a place of kindness, as people think Ava is always working. She said: Sheaposs my baby. She doesnapost usually work more than three hours a day and she has toys and treats and we go for off-lead walks and I take my cane and she can play. People donapost understand that sheaposs not working  . story: Family with boy, , kicked off Heathrow plane because child wouldn’t wear face maskAngela Artis, , who was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, claims her family were removed from an American Airlines flight that was connecting at Heathrow Airport as her son wouldnt keep a face mask onAngela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason Image: instagram so_angieByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum has claimed her family were kicked off an American Airlines flight after her two-year-old son wouldn’t keep his face mask on. Angela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason when they were forced off the plane at Heathrow where they were making a connection. Their holiday to Santorini, in Greece, where the couple were renewing their wedding vows, turned sour on thevia Heathrow. After being removed from the American Airlines flight  last Sunday, the airline provided overnight accommodation and rebooked the Artis family onto the following day’s flight. Mrs Artis claimed it was impossible to keep a mask on a two-year-old and that there was a baby near them that wasn’t forced to wear a face covering.  She said having got on board the plane initially everything was fine with the flight crew and her son was even given a lollipop. It turned sour, she claimed, when another flight attendant came over.She told the: “But about  minutes before the flight was due to take off another attendant came over and pointed a finger at my baby. She said aposhe needs to put a mask on or he’s got to go” in a very rude way.Mrs Artis said that her heart dropped as she had no idea it was a strict policy because she claimed that she had been able to travel before without him wearing a mask. Mrs Artis added that other flight crew in the past have accepted it is not feasible to keep the mask on a two-year-old “for more than five minutes”. She said: We had tried to put it on him for the first few minutes but he just couldn’t keep it on, it’s dficult for a baby to even physically breathe with a mask on. She said that the plane then taxied back to the terminal and the family was forced to get off the plan with an announcement that it was due to a child not wearing a mask. US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Transportation Security Administration directives mean that American Airlines requires passengers aged two and older to wear face coverings at all times while indoors at airports and onboard. In a statement, the airline said: On Oct. , American Airlines flight  ed to the gate prior to departure from London Heathrow to deplane a party failing to comply with the face mask requirement. After agreeing to comply with the face mask requirement, all iniduals were rebooked for travel on the next flight to Charlotte the following day. We are reviewing this incident and a member of our team has reached out to the customers to learn more about what took place. The Mirror has contacted American Airlines for further comment. story: Girl born without bones in her legs takes her first steps after amputationPosie-Aurora Sadler-Smith, now one, was diagnosed with limb problems during her -week-scan, but medics didnt know she had fibular hemimelia until she was born.The tot has defied all expectations Image: Jodie Weeder   SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience WriterKate Pounds:,  Oct | commentsItaposs always a special moment watching your child take their first steps - but for one couple, it was extra emotional. Their daughter Posie-Aurora Sadler-Smith, one, recently took her first steps - on her new prosthetic limbs after having an amputation. The tot was diagnosed with fibular hemimelia upon birth. The disability - where part or all of the fibula is missing - usually only impacts one leg, but Posie was missing nearly all the bones from both her lower limbs. But Posie defied the odds and learnt to crawl, using all her upper body strength to toddle around, and even boost herself on the sofa for a cuddle with pooch Seuss.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her parents faced the agonising decision on whether to amputate her limbs - in order to give her a chance at walking upright. And just after her first birthday, Posie had her left leg amputated at the ankle and was later fitted with prosthetic limbs - in her favourite shade of pink, naturally. She left her parents in floods of tears after taking her first tentative tiny steps, with her dadaposs support, later that day. Parents Jodie Weeder, , and partner Dominic Sadler-Smith, , admit they miss her perfect little toes but are in awe of their daughteraposs strength.  Jodie from Sudbury, Suffolk, said: When they strapped them on at the fitting it was like she suddenly wasnapost a baby anymore. She went suddenly from this little dinky girl to such a tall toddler. We never thought we would see her stand up. It was amazing. Prosthetics take a lot of getting used to, but It was amazing to see her stand up for the first time. She canapost stand on her own with them yet because the right one needs to be altered, so we have to hold her or she holds the furniture. Sheaposs incredible. Her upper body strength is amazing - sheaposs like a little Hulk. She fallsshe lets go, but she wonapost give up. She just gets up again. Sheaposll just try and try. Jodie, who has a cleaning business, and businessman Dominic, didnapost know whether their little girl would ever walk when they found she had a chromosomal condition at  weeks pregnant. We could have had a termination, but we werenapost giving up on her Jodie said. We just focussed on getting her here and thought: aposweaposll face whatever we faceapos. At birth, she was diagnosed with fibular hemimelia. She had no right knee or bones below it, and no left ankle with only one misshaped bone in that leg. Around one-in-fty-thousand little ones have the bone condition, but itaposs much rarer for both legs to be affected.She had to wear a brace to reposition her hips for three months. Determined Posie developed a speedy crawl at six months, and had her left foot amputated on July . Her right one remains but is shorter and missing toes. Emotional parents Jodie and Dominic watched as their only child stood for the first time when she got her first prosthetic legs on September . Her right knee is so unstable she canapost stand on her own yet, so doctors will help the family decide whether it would help Posie to amputate the right leg at her knee in October, to help her prosthetics fit better. Jodie said: Prosthetics take a lot of adjustment and getting used to: you donapost just pop them on for the first time and walk. As long as youaposve got the right support around you and people who love you are backing you you can do anything. There will always be hurdles out there in anyoneaposs le: youaposve just got to overcome them. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. story: Job advert for preschool worker praised for its hilariously honest requirementsJordan Jackson, the owner of Ladybridge Preschool in Bolton, posted a job advert telling candidates they would need to be fine leaving work each day "with unknown substances on your clothing" with colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PAY-Kennedy-News-and-Media.jpg" width"" "" Preschool owner Jordan Jacksonwith colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler Image: Kennedy News and MediaByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA preschool has been praised for its ultra honest job advert setting out the daily reality of working with small children - before adding: It really is all worth it. Ladybridge Preschool, based in Bolton, posted on social media to say it was on the lookout for a new recruit who could transform themselves into a Disney princess and be able to sing out of tune in front of a crowd of tiny humans. Other requirements for the job, which involves looking after children aged two to five, includes having eyes in the back of your head and offering big, warm hugs whenever required. The viral advert reads: You must be comfortable about entering public places on your way home from work with unknown substances on your clothing.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. You must have the ability to read a story book upside down, with at least five interruptions per page. And finally, you must be prepared to engage in lots of fun activities and be prepared to get messy. Your hair and nails will be hard to maintain, but it really is all worth it! Preschool owner Jordan Jackson decided to have fun with the job description and the honest advert appears to have worked perfectly, as she says they have been inundated with hopefuls applying for the role. The -year-old said: I was surprised by the reaction online. We have been inundated with applications which is great.  The way weaposve put it out has inspired people. Itaposs inspired people to apply and Iaposd loveother nurseries would advertise in the same way. I hope it inspires them. Weaposve had so many applicants and itaposs worked. She added: I was hoping to attract someone kind-hearted with a sense of humour. You have to have that. Our staff are all like this. Theyaposre energetic, bubbly, very outgoing. We try and make the setting a home-from-home - as happy as we can. [The post] shows them through the childaposs eyes and what they see. Weaposre extremely child-led. Jordan said the childrenaposs favourite activity is finding mini beasts hidden in shaving foam, and they also have a mud kitchen and an annual paint day, meaning both pupils and staff can get really messy. The owner took inspiration for the job advert from a similar listing written by Moorland Day Nursery in Bolton, and itaposs gone down a storm online. One person replied to say: This is the best job advert ever, and a second wrote: Perfect! I wish more places made job descriptions like this. title: know women being spiked needles
story: All we know about women being spiked with needles in UK nightclubs as MPs demand actionHome Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being spiked with needles at nightclubs across the countryZara Owen believes she was spiked with an injectionByWilliam JanesDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct  Dozens of young women have come forward to recall their terror in finding a prick in their arm or leg realising they had been spiked by injection in nightclubs.Several said they were avoiding clubs and house parties as a result - or were wearing thick denim to protect themselves. Police chiefs said plain clothes officers were likely to be deployed in nightclubs although womensapos groups warned some women struggled to trust forces in the wake of Sarah Everardaposs murderer.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.Universities have said they are working with bars and police to help ensure studentsapos safety after the reports.Have you been affected by this story  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Campaigners call for changes to make night venues safer Groups from more than  universities around the UK have joined an online campaign calling for the boycott of nightclubs. Campaigners say they are seeking tangible changes to make night-time venues safer, such as covers stoppers for drinks, better training for staff and more rigorous searches of clubbers. A petition to make it a legal requirement for nightclubs to thoroughly search guests on entry, started last week, has already gained more than , signatures. The National Union of Students issue statement Larissa Kennedy, president of the National Union of Students , said: Itaposs absolutely disgusting that in the past few days a number of students have reported instances of women being spiked on nights out. My rage, love and solidarity goes out to all those who have been impacted by these violent acts, and all other women and marginalised folks who experience sexual violence on our campuses and in our communities. One studentaposs story A student has told how she believes she was spiked with an injection during a night out with friends as police say reports of spiking are on the rise.Zara Owen, , from Surrey, who is a student at the University of Nottingham, said she went for a night out with friends last Monday but then blacked out soon after arriving at a venue.Speaking to BBC Breakfast, she said: I went out with my friends to a nightclub in the city - nothing more than what we would usually do. I remember going to the bar, going to the toilet, going to the photobooth, and then after that moment my memory is a blank until I get home and Iaposm getting my phone charger. I know I didnapost drink as much as I usually would on a night out this night, and the fact that I donapost remember anything is terrying for me because this is something that is a very rare occasion to me.  Iaposve never suffered with memory loss and then the next morning, obviously I did with the memory loss, I woke up with a really painful leg. I found a pin prick in my leg which was the epicentre of all pain. It made me unable to walk and I was limping around. As a young person whoaposs at university, Iaposm hearing stories of people who have been to nightclubs and they have been injected. I have heard stories of someone having it through their hand or through their back so this kind of gave me an idea this had happened to me. Ms Owen added she was afraid that she may have contracted a diseasea dirty needle had been used. What did the university say  A University of Nottingham spokesperson said: We are extremely concerned by these reports - no-one should feel unsafe on a night out. We are working closely with Nottinghamshire Police and the cityaposs nightle venues to monitor, review and learn from incidents and experiences in the city centre. We have contacted them about the specic concerns raised and will continue to liaise with them to actively tackle societal problems and challenge behaviours.The NHS website provides some guidelines on what to doyour skin has been punctured with a used needle. They advise to aposwash the wound using running water and plenty of soapapos, aposdry the wound and cover it with a waterproof plaster or dressingapos and to not scrub the wound or suck any blood. Nottingham Policeaposs websites has some guidance on what to doyour drink has been spiked, but they currently do not have any guidelines on being injected. They advise to: Tell the people you’re with and make sure you’re someone where you feel safe. Alert a member of staff at the pub or club you are at. If you feel unwell you should seek medical attention immediately and tell them that you believe your drink has been spiked.Police in Nottinghamshire investigateNottinghamshire Police has seen a rising number of reports of spiking over recent months and are now stepping up operations to tackle the problem. Superintendent Kathryn Craner said: Over the last few months we have seen an increase in reports where people believe that drugs may have been put in their drink - thataposs due to the fact that they have experienced a distinctly dferent feeling to their normal reaction to alcohol. But weaposve also received a small number of reports where people are telling us, as Zara has, that this has been associated with a pain or a mark on a part of their body, scratching sensation, and as though they have been physically spiked. The force has arrested a man as part of the wider operation to tackle spiking in Nottingham. Police Scotland also investigate reports Police are investigating reports of people being spiked by injection in the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas. It follows reports on social media about people being targeted inside venues in Scotland. Police Scotland said a small number of reports from the four areas are being investigated but do not appear to be linked. The force has also received a report of a drink-spiking incident at a venue in the Stirling area and inquiries are ongoing. A Police Scotland spokesman said: We are aware of posts circulating on social media about spiking incidents involving injections in Scotland. Officers are carrying out inquiries, and a small number of reports from the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas are being investigated. These do not appear to be linked. We take all reports seriously and we would encourage anyone who believes they have been a victim of spiking in any form to contact police via .  What politicians are saying about the issue“ These are obviously vile crimes,” said Commons Home Affairs Select Committee chairwoman Yvette Cooper.Ms Cooper, a former Shadow Home Secretary, said she received a report today from a victim who attended a hospital casualty unit last night “as a result of a possible injection spiking”. The victim “referred to there being three other people who were in the AE at the same time for spiking more widely, who were unable to walk as a result of drink spiking”.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.A Home Office source said: Weaposve asked the police to look into whataposs going on. We need to understand the scale of the problem. The thought of whataposs going on is just horrendous. What are the experts saying about it Some experts have cast doubt the use of needle spiking being a widespread phenomenon due to multiple iables such as the size of needle needed, the amount of liquid to cause an effect as well as the medical know-how needed to perform the injection.Guy Jones, senior scientist at drugs charity the Loop, told VICE World News: “GHB would be a poor candidate for injection due to the large amount of fluid needed, and therefore the thick, painful needle. This means that the substance involved would be something that would be highly detectable for several days in a toxicology screening such as a benzodiazepine.”David Caldicott, an emergency medicine consultant and founder of drug testing project WEDINOS, also said: “There are a couple of things that are disconcerting about this story. The technical and medical knowledge required to perform this would make this deeply improbable. It is at the level of a state-sponsored actor incapacitating a dissident, like the Novichok incident. The idea that a clubber would do this to a fellow clubber seems highly unlikely to me. news uk-news le-size--iron-man-"Manchester: Iron Man model sparks emergency responseByDianne BourneKate Buck:,  Oct | commentsA man was woken in the middle of the night by panicked police and paramedics after his custom-built le-size Iron Man statue sparked an emergency response.The homeowner in Deansgate Sqaure, Manchester, paid £, for the light-up figure which he says has been in his high-rise apartment for some time and has so far caused no issues.But he was awoken on Tuesday by a call from the concierge saying that police and ambulance crews were on their way up, Manchester Evening News reports. Crews had been called terried by the figure, thinking someone was hanging.When he let the -strong crew in they told him they were investigating reports of a concern for welfare.  Have you got a story youaposd like us to cover  Get in touch at webnews@mirrorThe man who has asked not to be named says: I was asleep in bed when I got a call from concierge to say the police were on their way up. I jumped out of bed in a scare I just totally panicked, I didnapost know what was going on, my kids were in the other room I had to check they were okay. I had police, paramedics, officers all come in. I switched on the lights and within minutes they realised it was the Iron Man sculpture and they just said aposwowapos and aposthataposs coolapos. The next thing they were taking selfies with it. It seems surreal now, but at the time it was really scary.  The man has lived in the flat for a year and said the sculpture has never caused any problems before now. Police officers told the man he should now move the sculpture as aposthe same thing could happen againapos, but he says itaposs simply too heavy. In a video from the scene, a police officer is heard saying: You need to move it, weaposll just keep getting calls. The homeowner is a fan of the Iron Man movies starring Robert Downey Jr, and bought the mammoth £, sculpture just before lockdown which features flashing eyes, chest and hands.  He says: Iaposve been here a year and no one has ever complained about the statue before. I mean we are really high up here. The officers were saying: you need to move Iron Manapos but itaposs just too heavy to do that. It was custom built and touches the ceiling. I just really like Iron Man and this lights up and everything, itaposs cool, I wanted it as a feature for the apartment. A spokesman for Greater Manchester Police said: At around pm last night , police were called to reports of a concern for welfare on Deansgate, Manchester. Emergency services attended and established that there was no cause for concern. title: londons thinnest home 6ft wide
story: Londons thinnest home at ft wide is on market for £k - but is yet to attract buyerThe architectural oddity, which is just ft at its narrowest point, is a two bedroom, two bathroom home set in historic former artist studiosLondons thinnest home - measuring just ft wide at its narrowest point Image: RightmoveByRory Bennett:,  Oct | commentsA two-bedroom flat dubbed ‘London’s thinnest house’ has been on the market at £k for two months, but it seems likely that potential buyers are being put off by a couple of practicalities. South Kensington’s famous  Thurloe Square, aka The Thin House, became available for £, earlier this year. The architectural oddity, which is just ft at its narrowest point, is a two bedroom, two bathroom home set in historic former artist studios. Images from Rightmove show the flat is kitted out with a modern kitchen and filled with natural light. It has an open plan living area, which is .m long by .m wide, and a very long, but very thin, terrace.  While the staged photos of the flat make it look very liveable, there are a couple of potential reasons why no one has snapped up the basement flat in the  months itaposs been on the market.Likely the main reason is also the explanation for the house’s thinness, My London reports. Unlike other houses on the street, The Thin House is almost directly conjoined with the tube line that runs along the back of the property.  This could also go to explain why buyers might not be keen to pay nearly  grand for a flat that is disturbed by the noise and vibrations of a busy tube line. The house was built in such a way that it almost feels like an optical illusion, with its unusual wedge shape design making the whole house look rather bizarre. Rightmove describes the flat on its website as: “A beautul  bedroom,  bathroom home in fantastic decorative order in historic former artist studios.  “Located on one of the best Garden Squares in Kensington and Cha with direct access to a South facing Patio   Terrace as well as access to the beautul and dog-friendly Thurloe Square Gardens,” the description continues. The flat is situated in one of Londonaposs most affluent neighbourhoods, with good transport links to the rest of the city. With the London property market once again ramping up after a lockdown lull it will be interesting to see who,anyone, snaps up this architectural anomaly. news uk-news mini-tornado-wreaks-havoc-after-"Falmouth hit by severe winds as sleepy town lashed by weatherByShabir NoorzaiChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mini-tornado has created havoc after rampaging through a sleeping Cornwall town overnight. Four people were rescued from the roof of their submerged car in the village of St Kew on Wednesday evening. Firemen in dry suits used ropes to rescue the occupants who were sitting on the roof of the stranded car in four feet of floodwater. Weather experts were checking out reports of a tornado in Falmouth, West Cornwall.Meanwhile, Devon County Councilaposs emergency centre said highways teams responded to  call-outs overnight as flooding hit parts of the region.Vehicles were stranded on bridges at Axminster in East Devon and there wereflood warnings on the rivers Clyst, Culm, Otter and Uplyme.Torrents of rainwater also flooded through village centres in east Devon causingdisruption.Locals in Widnes, Cheshire, posted videos of the damage created by the tornado, with collapsed garden walls, bins and roof tiles strewn across the middle of the road yesterday. During the night, the tornado was also seen ripping up trees and tearing down fences. The mini-tornado took place with reports of debris in and around Camberwell Park Road.  Local David Nevitt, who filmed some of the footage, said: I personally feel really lucky, my family and house are okay. Thereaposs an area nearby which has been hit really badly, they will be devastated by the damage. We very rarely get bad weather. One video shows debris strewn across the road, with tables and chairs having gone flying, and a fence - including its brick posts - thrown in the air and then dashed back down again.  A tree was also uprooted and could be seen across the road, while another video shows a large tree in someoneaposs front garden ripped out of the ground. A tornado is a violently rotating column of air that extends from a thunderstorm to the ground.A forecaster at the Met Office said it was entirely possible that a tornado had caused the damage. He said: The weather set-up in the area means that a tornado was possible around midday today in Widnes, although without clear footage of the event itaposs dficult to confirm whether the damaging winds were from a tornado or not. The Met Office had a thunderstorm warning in place in the area throughout the morning, and further unsettled weather was forecast for the afternoon, although itaposs impossible to forecast specic tornado events with any degree of confidence. Tornadoes are not uncommon in the UK and we get, on average, around  per year, though numbers can y markedly from year to year. Tornado reports in the UK tend to be mainly in summer and autumn. Tornadoes in the UK are usually relatively narrow and short-lived affairs, typically lasting for only a few minutes and with tracks no more than a few kilometres long and a diameter of less than - metres. shower is a spectacle like no other, giving skygazers a chance to see pieces from the famous Halleyaposs Commet. The comet only passes earth every  or  years, but luckily itaposs possible to see the debris in the form of shooting stars every October.Luckily, the  Orionid meteor shower will be visible across the whole globe – including the UK. According to the Royal Museums Greenwich , the Orionids is one of the best known and most reliable meteor showers in the annual calendar. Andy McCrea, from the Irish Astronomical Association, also says that this particular meteor shower is extra special due to the sheer speed and brightness of the shooting stars.  Here is everything you need to know about spotting them tonight in the UK. What is the Orionid meteor shower  The Orionid meteor shower occurs every year sometime between October  to November . At its peak, up to  meteors are visible every hour. The Orionids receives it name because the meteors seem to emerge, or radiate, from the same are as the constellation. According to RMG, some people also view this particular meteor shower as extra special because the meteors are pieces of the famous Comet P Halley, or Halleyaposs Comet.  This famous comet only swings by earth every  to  years, which means those who may never see the one-in-a-letime event will get some compensation. What time will the Orionids peak in the UK  The Orionids are usually active between October  and November , but this year the peak falls tonight, on October .Luckily, the meteor shower can be seen across both the northern and southern hempishere, so it will be clearly visible from the UK – weather permitting. According to RMG, youaposll want to find a safe location away from street lights and other sources of light pollution. It continues: The meteors can be seen in all parts of the sky, so it’s good to be in a wide open space where you can scan the night sky with your eyes. story: Pub-goer reports BBC star James Naughtie to police after spotting him drink drivingGordon Duncan spoke of how he witnessed James Naughtie “gulp down” the big glass of wine while chatting away to someone in the bar in Edinburgh, Scotland, before jumping into his car to drive homeJames Naughtie has been fined a total of £ and banned from driving for  months Image: PAByIona Young:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA pub-goer has shared how he reported a BBC radio presenter to police for drink driving. James Naughtie, , was spotted by Gordon Duncan downing a “large Chardonnay” at Bennet’s bar, in the Edinburgh suburb of Morningside in Scotland, before leaving to drive home. Gordon, who was previously a regular at the bar, was shocked when he noticed the presenter getting into his car, and reported the series of events to police. Gordon hasn’t felt comfortable going back to the pub he spent  years as a regular since the incident, he said.Speaking to Edinburgh Live, Gordon spoke of how he witnessed Naughtie “gulp down” the big glass of wine while chatting away to someone in the bar.“On this I decided to go outside and pretend I was on a call in the Bennets garden,” he said.  “The guy came out  minutes later and got into his new car and drove off. I took a picture of his car and noted the number plate too. “I then called police immediately.” Gordon explained that he doesn’t believe in drink drivers”. “Itaposs disgusting in this day and age where we have one of the best public services. People who drink drive should be sent to prison,” he said. “I was never afraid to report him, I hate drink drivers I would report him again or someone doing same thing.  Naughtie, , was spotted getting into his car after he had stopped off for a glass of wine at Bennets Bar in Morningside, Edinburgh. The award-winning journalist was traced to his nearby capital home by police officers and admitted he had been driving his vehicle that afternoon in October . He was asked was to provide a roadside breath test and was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath. The legal limit is just mg of alcohol. The retired Radio  news anchor appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court under his full name of Alexander James Naughtie in June where he pleaded guilty to driving while over the limit. Prosecutor Ross Price said: “Around pm in the afternoon the accused left Bennet’s Bar and a member of staff saw him getting into his vehicle and called police. “Officers made enquiries and attended at the accused’s home address at .pm and breathalysed him. “He confirmed he was the driver [of the vehicle] that afternoon.” Solicitor Sean Flanagan, defending, said his client had been driving to his Edinburgh home and decided to stop off at the public house “for one glass of wine”. The lawyer added Naughtie, whose address was given as Blackthorn Avenue, London, had only driven “a relatively short distance” from the bar to his home and had cooperated fully with police. Sherf Peter McCormack fined the motorist a total of £ and banned him from driving for  months. The sherf said Naughtie would be allowed to take part in a drink drive rehabilitation schemehe chooses which,passed successfully, would see his road ban reduced by three months. Naughtie pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at Maxwell Street, Morningside Road and Cluny Gardens, all Edinburgh, on October , . title: queen urged step one side
story: Queen urged to step to one side after being ordered to rest by doctorsThe -year-old monarch cancelled her trip to Northern Ireland after her doctor advised her to take a few days off and rest after a hectic few weeksThe Queen was told to take a few days of rest after a busy few weeks of travelling and hosting events Image: Getty ImagesByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Queen should step to one side after being told to rest by doctors, a royal source has claimed. Her Majesty, , was forced to cancel her two-day trip to Northern Ireland after being advised take some time out of her schedule. She pulled out of the trip just five hours before she was due to arrive. Buckingham Palace said in a statement: “The Queen has reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days. “Her Majesty is in good spirits and is disappointed that she will no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland, where she had been due to undertake a series of engagements today and tomorrow. “The Queen sends her warmest good wishes to the people of Northern Ireland, and looks forward to visiting in the future.” The Northern Ireland trip was cancelled so last minute palace staff were already waiting in Belfast, the Mail Online reports.  A royal source said of the Queen: With her Platinum Jubilee on the horizon, many are thinking that perhaps her private office needs to look at the diary again. Another source added: No one is saying that she should take a step back, but perhaps another slight step to one side might be in order.  It has been confirmed that the monarch is not sick due to Covid-, and that she simply needed to rest after a busy schedule and weeks of travelling. This week the Queen welcomed guests following Boris Johnsonaposs investment summit. She met with business leaders, tech entrepreneurs and politicians, including the the Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. The monarch also recently ed from a summer in Balmoral, and opened the Welsh Senedd last week. Over the weekend, she had attended the Ascot races and on Monday met with new governor-general of New Zealand virtually.Also last week, the Queen had attended a service at Westminster Abbey for the Royal British Legion, where she was spotted with a walking stick for the first time. The Palace has insisted that there is nothing to be concerned about and that her doctor instructed her to rest.  The Northern Ireland trip would have seen the Queen attend a service marking the centenary of the partition of Ireland and the formation of Northern Ireland. She was also due to visit Hillsborough Castle, which was renamed to the Royal Hillsborough Castle, and would have met with some pandemic heroes. This is not the first time the Queen has been forced to cancel a trip. In January of last year, she was due to visit the Womenaposs Institutebranch in Sandringham, Norfolk but did not attend due to ill health. She was also forced to cancel her appearance at an event at St Pauls in London in June  because she was feeling ill. story: All secondary school pupils and staff in entire county told to wear masks againSecondary school pupils and staff in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again as Covid cases continue to rise, with hospitalisations up in all regions of England" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Masks-Compulsory-For-Secondary-School-Students-In-Scotland.jpg" width"" "" Secondary school pupils and staff in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again Image: Getty ImagesByKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsSecondary school staff and pupils in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again as Covid cases continue to rise. Stuart Keeble, Suffolk County Councilaposs director of public health, told BBC Radio aposs Today programme that the virus is really working its way through that younger population at the moment. For me now it is also about trying to keep children in school. We have had around , pupils test positive in the last  days. If we can keep transmission rates down, we can also keep more pupils in school as well while the vaccine is being run out for  to -year-olds. He added that there was the risk the virus could spread through school children to the older population, their parents and grandparents.  Mr Keeble added: We have started to see that. We have started to see an increase over the last few weeks in that parent age group of those in secondary school. He also said they are now also increase in cases in over-s and this is a concern given, there are more vulnerable people in those age groups. This comes amidst growing concerns as cases and hospitalisations continue to rise in the UK as the country heads towards winter. Covid hospitalisations are up in every region of England and Wales, with the South East seeing the most dramatic increase of a % rise in hospitalisations in one week.  With , new covid cases yesterday, October , there has been growing calls for a ‘Plan B’ to deal with the issue.However, in a press conference yesterday health secretary Sajid Javid pushed back against the need for a ‘Plan B’ saying it was not time for it yet.He said that the NHS was not yet under “unsustainable” pressure and called on Brits to show their “Blitz spirit” and get their Covid booster jab.. Despite the NHS Confederation calling for a new approach, Javid said: I’ve got a lot of time for the NHS Confederation… they do a lot of good work.  On this particular question we don’t believe the pressures currently faced by the NHS are unsustainable. Donapost get me wrong, there are huge pressures, especially in AE, in primary care for example as well. But at this point we donapost believe they are unsustainable. He did call upon people to continue to wear face masks in enclosed spaces, but stopped short of making it mandatory. Javid warned that restrictions would “of course” Brits did not wear masks or get their booster jabs when able to. title: six things learnt meghans mom
story: Six things we learnt from Meghan’s mom letter - overwhelmed by Lilibet and cheap treatMeghan Markle has written an emotional letter calling for families in America to be given paid leave from work - and in it, she revealed several things about her childhood and le as a mumMeghan Markle with husband Prince Harry and son Archie Image: Getty ImagesByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsMeghan Markle has penned a powerful letter calling for paid leave for all new parents in America.And her passionate plea has seen her reveal several things about her own experiences growing up with her family and becoming mum to Archie and Lilibet. Meghan addressed the letter to Senate Leader Chuck Schumer and Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi, acknowledging she is not an elected official or politician, but wanted to speak as a mom on the issue.She also wrote about the sacrices working parents have to make not just in pursuit of the American Dream, but simply the dream of stability. Here we look at some of the things weaposve learnt about Meghan from her emotional letter... Meghan enjoyed eating out for . as a child  In a bid to highlight her point about why paid leave is important for parents, Meghan drew on her own experiences as a child. And she recalled how going to eat out would be a special occasion as she could only do it thanks to her parentsapos hard work. She wrote: I grew up on the .salad bar at Sizzler - it may have cost less back then- but what I do remember was the feeling: I knew how hard my parents worked to afford this because even at five bucks, eating out was something special, and I felt lucky. And as a Girl Scout, when my troop would go for dinner for a big celebration, it was back to that same salad bar or The Old Spaghetti Factory - because thataposs what those families could afford to do too. She had to work from aged  to make ends meet Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .Meghan also revealed her experiences of holding down a series of jobs since the age of  in order to make ends meet. She wrote in the letter: I started workingat the age of . I waited tables, babysat and piecemealed jobs together to cover odds and ends. I worked all my le and saved where I could - but even that was a luxury - because it was usually about making ends meet and having enough to pay my rent or put gas in my car. She and Prince Harry were aposoverwhelmedapos after Lilibetaposs birthMeghan and husband Prince Harry are parents to two children - two-year-old Archie and four-month-old Lilibet.And according to Meghan both she and Harry were overwhelmed following Lilibetaposs arrival. She said in the letter: In June, my husband and I welcomed our second child. Like any parents, we were overjoyed. Like many parents, we were overwhelmed. Meghan didnapost have to worry about going back to work after Lilibet arrived Meghan points out that she and Harry were among the lucky minority that they werenapost faced with having toto work soon after Lilibetaposs birth. She revealed: Like fewer parents, we werenapost confronted with the harsh reality of either spending those first few critical months with our baby or going back to work. We knew we could take her home, and in that vitalstage, devote any and everything to our kids and to our family. We knew that by doing so we wouldnapost have to make impossible choices about childcare, work and medical care that so many have to make every single day. No family should be faced with these decisions. No family should have to chose between earning a living and having the freedom to take care of their child . Meghan believes paid leave should be a right  In a direct plea, Meghan calls for paid leave to be a national right for every American. She argues: Paid leave should be a national right, rather than a patchwork option limited to those whose employers have policies in place, or those who live in one of the few states where a leave program exists. If weaposre going to create a new era of family-first policies, letaposs make sure that includes a strong paid leave program for every American thataposs guaranteed, accessible, and encouraged without stigma or penalty. Meghan understands how isive politics has become In her letter, Meghan talks about the current political landscape and says she thanks politicians for considering her letter on behalf of her family Archie, Lili and Harry. She revealed: I know how politically charged things can – and have – become. But this isnapost about right or left, itaposs about right or wrong. This is about putting families above politics. And for a refreshing change, itaposs something we all seem to agree on. At a point when everything feels so isive, let this be a shared goal that unites us. So, on behalf of my family, Archie and Lili and Harry, I thank you for considering this letter, and on behalf of all families, I ask you to ensure this consequential moment is not lost.
